articles.headline: Spanx Tries to Loosen Up Its Image
articles.snippet: The Spanx line of figure-sculpting bras and bodysuits aims to stay relevant as women increasingly embrace their curves and bumps.
articles.abstract: The Spanx line of figure-sculpting bras and bodysuits aims to stay relevant as women increasingly embrace their curves and bumps.
articles.lead_paragraph: Spanx, the flab-obscuring, body-sculpting line of bras and bodysuits, helped a generation of women squeeze into ever-tinier dresses.

articles.headline: Brian Williams Inquiry Is Said to Expand
articles.snippet: An internal inquiry is examining a half-dozen instances in which Mr. Williams is thought to have embellished his accounts, including an episode involving statements he made about events in Cairo during the Arab Spring.
articles.abstract: An internal inquiry is examining a half-dozen instances in which Mr. Williams is thought to have embellished his accounts, including an episode involving statements he made about events in Cairo during the Arab Spring.
articles.lead_paragraph: An NBC News internal investigation into Brian Williams has examined a half-dozen instances in which he is thought to have fabricated, misrepresented or embellished his accounts, two people with inside knowledge of the investigation said.

articles.headline: Comcast Withdraws Purchase Bid, but It Isn’t Going Anywhere
articles.snippet: Comcast suffered a setback as it canceled its offer for Time Warner Cable, but the executive at the company’s helm will likely continue in his father’s footsteps as a daring deal maker.
articles.abstract: Comcast suffered a setback as it canceled its offer for Time Warner Cable, but the executive at the company’s helm will likely continue in his father’s footsteps as a daring deal maker.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a boy, Brian L. Roberts watched his father, Ralph, build Comcast into a cable empire.

articles.headline: Intense Lobbying Failed to Assure Comcast’s Deal
articles.snippet: Congress has no direct power to approve or disapprove any merger, but endorsements can send a subtle but important message to regulators that the deal is in the public interest and should be cleared.
articles.abstract: Congress has no direct power to approve or disapprove any merger, but endorsements can send a subtle but important message to regulators that the deal is in the public interest and should be cleared.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — David L. Cohen, the master salesman who runs the Comcast Corporation’s lobbying efforts, stood before a room full of Latino House lawmakers one morning in early December trying to convince them that they should embrace his $45 billion deal to acquire Time Warner Cable.

articles.headline: Baltimore’s ‘Broken Relationship’ With Police
articles.snippet: The city’s history helps explain the long-simmering anger that boiled over this week with the death of Freddie Gray, who suffered a severe spinal cord injury in police custody.
articles.abstract: The city’s history helps explain the long-simmering anger that boiled over this week with the death of Freddie Gray, who suffered a severe spinal cord injury in police custody.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — For nearly two years, ever since her brother Tyrone West died after a struggle with the police, a 35-year-old preschool teacher named Tawanda Jones has been in the streets here on Wednesday nights, protesting. Her message: “We need killer cops in cellblocks.”

articles.headline: Earthquake Devastates Nepal, Killing More Than 1,900
articles.snippet: The earthquake struck near Katmandu. Residents described scenes of panic, and trekkers reported a major avalanche on Mount Everest.
articles.abstract: The earthquake struck near Katmandu. Residents described scenes of panic, and trekkers reported a major avalanche on Mount Everest.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A powerful earthquake shook Nepal on Saturday near its capital, Katmandu, killing more than 1,900 people, flattening sections of the city’s historic center, and trapping dozens of sightseers in a 200-foot watchtower that came crashing down into a pile of bricks.

articles.headline: Scott Walker, a Pastor’s Son, Runs on Faith as Iowa Beckons
articles.snippet: Mr. Walker’s lifelong church involvement may be a powerful asset as he positions himself to run for president and focuses on states dominated by evangelical voters.
articles.abstract: Mr. Walker’s lifelong church involvement may be a powerful asset as he positions himself to run for president and focuses on states dominated by evangelical voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Scott Walker, the son of a Baptist preacher, learned a lot about being a politician by going to church.

articles.headline: Thomas Staggs: Disney’s Heir, Apparently
articles.snippet: The executive must walk one of corporate America’s most daunting gantlets, working to convince board members that he is up to the task of being chief executive.
articles.abstract: The executive must walk one of corporate America’s most daunting gantlets, working to convince board members that he is up to the task of being chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert A. Iger was grasping for words. Standing before shareholders in San Francisco last month, the normally quick-witted Mr. Iger, chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, had been caught off guard by Brooke Ledwith, an inquisitive 6-year-old. “Who was the first Disney princess to walk on a Disney cruise ship?” she asked, standing on tiptoe to reach a microphone.

articles.headline: Tempur Sealy Shareholder Clamors to Shake Up an Entrenched Board
articles.snippet: When investors in the mattress maker convene next month, they will decide whether three top officials, including the chief executive, should be ousted.
articles.abstract: When investors in the mattress maker convene next month, they will decide whether three top officials, including the chief executive, should be ousted.
articles.lead_paragraph: Should they stay or should they go?

articles.headline: Russian Hackers Read Obama’s Unclassified Emails, Officials Say
articles.snippet: The hackers did not appear to have penetrated closely guarded servers that control the message traffic from President Obama’s personal BlackBerry, officials said.
articles.abstract: The hackers did not appear to have penetrated closely guarded servers that control the message traffic from President Obama’s personal BlackBerry, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some of President Obama’s email correspondence was swept up by Russian hackers last year in a breach of the White House’s unclassified computer system that was far more intrusive and worrisome than has been publicly acknowledged, according to senior American officials briefed on the investigation.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Deep Support in Washington for C.I.A.’s Drone Missions
articles.snippet: Unwavering support from Capitol Hill is but one reason the C.I.A.’s killing missions are unlikely to change significantly, despite the revelation Thursday that a drone strike had killed two hostages.
articles.abstract: Unwavering support from Capitol Hill is but one reason the C.I.A.’s killing missions are unlikely to change significantly, despite the revelation Thursday that a drone strike had killed two hostages.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — About once a month, staff members of the congressional intelligence committees drive across the Potomac River to C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va., and watch videos of people being blown up.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Gay Marriage Case Caps Cincinnati’s Shift From Conservative Past
articles.snippet: As the Supreme Court prepares to hear oral arguments on same-sex marriage, Cincinnati has become the measure of how far the gay rights movement has come in a traditionally conservative city.
articles.abstract: As the Supreme Court prepares to hear oral arguments on same-sex marriage, Cincinnati has become the measure of how far the gay rights movement has come in a traditionally conservative city.
articles.lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Jim Obergefell says he “instantly pictured growing old” with John Arthur when they fell in love here in 1992. Just seven weeks after they began dating, Mr. Arthur gave Mr. Obergefell a ring set with diamonds — a sign that, in their hearts if not in law, they were married.

articles.headline: Earthquake Aftershocks Jolt Nepal as Death Toll Rises Above 3,400
articles.snippet: Residents were on a difficult search for safety in Katmandu, where thousands have died and homes and temples have been reduced to rubble.
articles.abstract: Residents were on a difficult search for safety in Katmandu, where thousands have died and homes and temples have been reduced to rubble.
articles.lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal — Each time this city shuddered with aftershocks from the earthquake that convulsed Nepal, Samaj Gautam felt an urge to join the millions of residents who fled to safety outdoors. But working in a hospital emergency ward inundated with the wounded, and their broken limbs, fractured skulls and other physical traumas, Dr. Gautam said Sunday night, he and his colleagues had to suppress their fears and stick to treating patients.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: Turning a Children’s Rating System Into an Advocacy Army
articles.snippet: James Steyer’s nonprofit organization, Common Sense Media, is known for offering parents guidance on games and videos, but he has a grander vision.
articles.abstract: James Steyer’s nonprofit organization, Common Sense Media, is known for offering parents guidance on games and videos, but he has a grander vision.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — James P. Steyer came here from San Francisco last week on a whirlwind tour to try to engage the country’s power brokers in his new crusade to put children and education at the top of the nation’s political agenda.

articles.headline: Burdened With Debt, Law School Graduates Struggle in Job Market
articles.snippet: About 20 percent of 2010 graduates have jobs that do not require a law license, a new study shows, and only 40 percent are working in law firms.
articles.abstract: About 20 percent of 2010 graduates have jobs that do not require a law license, a new study shows, and only 40 percent are working in law firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jonathan Wang has not practiced law since he graduated from Columbia Law School in 2010, but he did not plan it that way.

articles.headline: Concerns on Jeep Safety Remain, Despite Recall
articles.snippet: Regulators are considering whether to reopen an investigation into Jeeps with rear gas tanks, despite Fiat Chrysler’s agreement two years ago to recall some of the affected models.
articles.abstract: Regulators are considering whether to reopen an investigation into Jeeps with rear gas tanks, despite Fiat Chrysler’s agreement two years ago to recall some of the affected models.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Since its bankruptcy and government bailout in 2009, the American automaker Chrysler has made a stirring comeback primarily by expanding sales of its popular Jeep sport utility vehicles.

articles.headline: The Latest Fashion, Trending on Google
articles.snippet: The search giant is scanning its wealth of user-generated data for signs of fashion trends as it works to enhance its sales of online advertisements.
articles.abstract: The search giant is scanning its wealth of user-generated data for signs of fashion trends as it works to enhance its sales of online advertisements.
articles.lead_paragraph: Normcore? So last year. String bikinis? Most definitely over.

articles.headline: Comcast-Time Warner Cable Deal’s Collapse Leaves Frustrated Customers Out in the Cold
articles.snippet: As soon as Comcast withdrew, Charter Communications was reported to be exploring a new bid for Time Warner Cable, but some predict consumers will lose no matter who buys whom.
articles.abstract: As soon as Comcast withdrew, Charter Communications was reported to be exploring a new bid for Time Warner Cable, but some predict consumers will lose no matter who buys whom.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the vast realm of unhappy cable customers, Time Warner Cable subscribers stand out as an especially miserable bunch.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Struggling With Shifts on Gay Marriage
articles.snippet: Once a winning primary issue as well as a powerful wedge issue, same-sex marriage has grown far more complicated for Republicans.
articles.abstract: Once a winning primary issue as well as a powerful wedge issue, same-sex marriage has grown far more complicated for Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rick Santorum said he would never attend a same-sex wedding. Marco Rubio said he might attend one. Scott Walker actually went to a same-sex wedding reception, not to be confused with an actual same-sex wedding ceremony. Ted Cruz said he is firmly opposed to gay marriage, but would be comfortable if his daughter were gay.

articles.headline: Downside of Police Body Cameras: Your Arrest Hits YouTube
articles.snippet: While some departments cite privacy concerns or the administrative burden of making the videos available to the public, the Seattle police post everything.
articles.abstract: While some departments cite privacy concerns or the administrative burden of making the videos available to the public, the Seattle police post everything.
articles.lead_paragraph: Police departments around the country have been moving with unusual speed to equip officers with body cameras to film their often edgy encounters with the public. But the adoption of these cameras has created a new conflict over who has the right to view the recordings.

articles.headline: In an Already Troubled Nepal, a Picture of Despair Emerges
articles.snippet: Nepal was in political and economic disarray well before a powerful earthquake on Saturday shattered buildings, and lives.
articles.abstract: Nepal was in political and economic disarray well before a powerful earthquake on Saturday shattered buildings, and lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Her home and village near the earthquake’s epicenter were destroyed, her grandfather was killed, and no one from outside the village — not a soldier, police officer or rescue worker — had arrived to help.

articles.headline: Drought Frames Economic Divide of Californians
articles.snippet: The persistent water shortage is illustrating parallel worlds in which wealthy communities guzzle water as poorer neighbors conserve by necessity.
articles.abstract: The persistent water shortage is illustrating parallel worlds in which wealthy communities guzzle water as poorer neighbors conserve by necessity.
articles.lead_paragraph: COMPTON, Calif. — Alysia Thomas, a stay-at-home mother in this working-class city, tells her children to skip a bath on days when they do not play outside; that holds down the water bill. Lillian Barrera, a housekeeper who travels 25 miles to clean homes in Beverly Hills, serves dinner to her family on paper plates for much the same reason. In the fourth year of a severe drought, conservation is a fine thing, but in this Southern California community, saving water means saving money.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Baltimore Enlists National Guard and a Curfew to Fight Riots and Looting
articles.snippet: Several officers were injured as police cars were damaged and rocks were thrown. Protesters smashed windows, and a CVS drugstore was set on fire.
articles.abstract: Several officers were injured as police cars were damaged and rocks were thrown. Protesters smashed windows, and a CVS drugstore was set on fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Maryland’s governor activated the National Guard on Monday and the city of Baltimore announced a curfew for all residents as a turbulent day that began with the funeral of 25-year-old Freddie Gray, the nation’s latest symbol of police brutality, ended with rioting by rock-throwing youths, arson, looting and at least 15 police officers injured.

articles.headline: Nepal Villages Cut Off by Earthquake Wait for Aid as Death Toll Passes 4,000
articles.snippet: Residents of the Gorkha district say houses collapsed, food is running out and so far no one has arrived with aid.
articles.abstract: Residents of the Gorkha district say houses collapsed, food is running out and so far no one has arrived with aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAURPANI, Nepal — Five hours by car from Katmandu, then by foot for several miles past the spot where the road is blocked by boulders and mud, people from the villages near the epicenter of Nepal’s powerful earthquake are burying their dead, despairing of help arriving anytime soon.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Lawyers Seek Sea Change on Gay Rights at Supreme Court
articles.snippet: Those arguing against states’ bans on same-sex marriage hope the justices will reach a bold verdict that would transform the status of gay Americans.
articles.abstract: Those arguing against states’ bans on same-sex marriage hope the justices will reach a bold verdict that would transform the status of gay Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the months leading to Tuesday’s Supreme Court arguments on same-sex marriage, teams of gay rights lawyers and their allies have held countless strategy sessions, drafted scores of briefs and participated in intense moot courts.

articles.headline: Trans-Pacific Partnership Puts Harvard Law School Rivals on Opposite Sides, Again
articles.snippet: Michael Froman, the United States trade representative championing the pact, keeps running into a familiar nemesis, the anti-globalization leader Lori Wallach.
articles.abstract: Michael Froman, the United States trade representative championing the pact, keeps running into a familiar nemesis, the anti-globalization leader Lori Wallach.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the early 2000s, after Michael Froman decamped from the Clinton Treasury Department for Wall Street, he called his old law school colleague Lori Wallach, now an anti-globalization activist, with an unusual proposal.
